abstracts.cdata!:
The Transport Parastatals Project for
            Nigeria achieved an unsatisfactory overall outcome.
            Sustainability is rated as unlikely. The locomotive spare
            parts financed under the project did not yield the expected
            benefits. Institutional development is rated as negligible.
            The Bank's performance is rated as unsatisfactory as
            supervision effectiveness was hampered by high staff
            turnover and a lack of specialized skills. The
            Borrower's performance was also unsatisfactory. The
            failure to provide adequate project support indicated a lack
            of full Borrower commitment to the project and account in
            large part for the lack of achievement of the project. The
            objectives of the project were only partly achieved. A
            number of useful studies were performed which laid out some
            of the foundation for the reform of transport parastatals,
            covering actuarial and asset valuation, manpower
            rationalization, policy formulation, and decision making for
            transport parastatals. However, little was accomplished
            toward improving the efficiency of the parastatals. The
            three main lessons learned are: (i) a broad scope project
            such as this one requires supervision missions carefully
            balanced between persons with specialized skills and persons
            of broad experience; (ii) Project Coordinating Units are not
            suited to ensure internalization and follow-up of complex
            reorganization studies, particularly in parastatals; and
            (iii) adequate management tools and organizational changes
            should be established ahead of project effectiveness to
            generate measurable improvements of operating performance.
